The structure is found to be in the ice II structure, which is a key to understanding the origin of water’s unique properties. The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a topic of intense current interest. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum theory. Our characterization is based on a set of axioms that are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. Our results provide a mathematical foundation for the program of showing that the category of Hilbert space operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between Banach spaces. This is a central result in the reconstruction of quantum mechanics from the category of observables.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that are the most diverse group of parasitic animals. They are also the most enigmatic, with a long-standing debate about their evolutionary origin. Here, we report the first genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two species of myxozoans, and we compare these to the genome of a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is the result of a dramatic reduction in gene content and genome size. This reduction is accompanied by the loss of key signaling pathways and transcriptional factors, suggesting that the myxozoan transition to parasitism was accompanied by a reduction in complexity. Our results provide insights into the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitic animals. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we describe a mechanism of viral antagonism in which SARS-CoV-2 hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to impair nuclear import of importin/karyopherin, which is a key step in the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of Nup98-Rae1 in the antiviral action of IFN and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase to 86% under 4 °C of global warming. This study also highlights the importance of heat tolerance in maize breeding to ensure food security in the face of climate change.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet composition for seven species of African LMH, and found that the degree of overlap in diet composition was greater between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption than within them. These results suggest that the extent to which LMH partition food resources may be more limited than is currently recognized, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages. Our findings highlight the need for more comprehensive, species-level diet analyses in future studies of LMH ecology and coexistence.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but we find that many anticipate problems with accessing the program. Our results suggest that the CARES Act should be supplemented with grants to help small businesses survive the crisis.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, mostly because of the action of size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The age of the solar system is a key issue in astronomy. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. We determined that at least 12 of the analyzed grains were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. The results are important for the understanding of the formation of the solar system and the evolution of the early solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded dramatically. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to provide resources to offspring is a defining characteristic of the evolution of animal societies. Here, we show that the evolution of sociality, in the form of domestication and allonursing, is associated with an increase in the reproductive output of the mother. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is due to an increase in the energy available to the mother rather than an increase in the number of litters. This result suggests that the limiting factor in the evolution of placental mammals is the mother’s metabolic power rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is the most toxic form of the protein. Our results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other α-syn aggregation disorders. (Show more)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to communicate with other cells in the body, and this communication is critical for the proper functioning of the cardiovascular system. This paper describes the structure of the endothelial communication network and the properties of the network that make it effective for the rapid and efficient control of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic, responding to it, and planning for the future. We describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides a wide range of public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, all available at a fine geographic resolution and updated daily. The data are available through an API and accompanying software packages, and are described in detail in this paper. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers in their efforts to understand and respond to the pandemic.

The selectivity filter and the activation gate in potassium channels are functionally and structurally coupled. This coupling is mediated by an allosteric mechanism, which is triggered by opening the activation gate. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter is a prerequisite for C-type inactivation gating. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural basis for the gating mechanism of this important family of ion channels.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is an active area of research, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome is an area of interest. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize a variety of natural products. These natural products could be used as a source of new antibiotics and other bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, but the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies is largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is mediated by the nucleus accumbens and that the brain energy metabolism in this region is crucial for social hierarchy establishment. Our findings suggest that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. They also highlight the importance of mitochondrial function in the brain for social behavior. (Show more)

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great significance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of complex structures with specific responses is challenging due to the complexity of the design space and the difficulty of finding the optimal solution. Here, we propose a method to synthesize mechanical structures with specific responses through a digital design approach. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their responses are physically realized. The proposed method can be extended to design structures with complex responses and can be applied to a wide range of applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major determinant of the lifespan of the human body. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of aging. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of evolution. Here we show that the hemoglobin system is also a major target of chronoregulation. We show that the hemoglobin system is regulated by a downstream element of the let-7 miRNA pathway, the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), and that this element is developmentally silenced in the fetal liver and is expressed in erythroid cells. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates posttranscriptional loss of the BCL11A transcription factor, which is a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. They also suggest that the hemoglobin system may be a target of evolution.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of cancer cell resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis through induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. Genetic or pharmacologic ablation of SREBP1 or its transcriptional target stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1 (SCD1) sensitized cancer cells to ferroptosis, and the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction showed therapeutic promise in preclinical models. Our findings provide a rationale for the development of ferroptosis-inducing agents in combination with mTORC1 inhibitors for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of cardiovascular disease prevention. The most widely used drugs for treating hypertension are L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the long-term use of LCCBs is associated with the development of heart failure. Our study reveals that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but the policy has not yet reversed the decline of older forest bird populations. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy on biodiversity. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the development of older-forest structure.

The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to combat the growing problem of antibiotic resistance. In this work, we present a rational design strategy to identify new antibiotics. The strategy is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics to the ribosome. We show that the best candidate, which was predicted by our strategy, is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, the only approved acylide antibiotic, and is active against multiple antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The strategy can be used to identify new antibiotics with improved properties, which is essential for the development of new drugs. This work is expected to contribute to the fight against antibiotic resistance. (Show more)

We introduce a new deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters. The network architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales, and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting network architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems. The code for the proposed architecture is available at this https URL .

The Lake Malawi cichlid fish are a globally unique group of endemic species that have evolved in a single lake over millions of years. The lake is a unique system, with a large, shallow lake that has changed dramatically in size and shape over time. We present a continuous record of the hydroclimate of the lake over the last 1.3 My, which shows that the lake has changed dramatically in size and shape over time. The record shows that the lake has been much larger in the past, and that the lake level has changed dramatically over time, with periods of extreme drought and periods of extreme wetness. The record also shows that the climate was drier before the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, and wetter after the transition. The record provides a unique insight into the evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish, and the processes that have shaped the evolution of the lake and its ecosystem. (Less)

The use of electronic devices, such as tablets and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past 50 y. This study shows that the use of these devices in the hours before bedtime has a significant impact on sleep. The use of these devices before bedtime has been shown to suppress melatonin levels, phase-shift the circadian clock, and reduce alertness the following morning. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Ytterby meteorite, which fell in Sweden in 1911, is the only known source of magnetic microspherules. The Ytterby magnetic microspherules are used as a marker for the YDB. However, the origin of the magnetic microspherules is still controversial. We show that the magnetic microspherules are not of extraterrestrial origin, but are derived from a terrestrial source. The source of the magnetic microspherules is the Grenville Province of northeastern North America, which is 1.5 Ga old. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic microspherules indicate that the source lies in the Grenville Province. The rare earth element patterns of the magnetic microspherules are similar to those of the Grenville Province, indicating that the magnetic microspherules are derived from the Grenville Province.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the developmental stage of the immune system.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their diversity remains unclear. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of their food sources, and that the evolution of their food sources is linked to the evolution of their genes.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to both evolutionary psychologists and cultural evolutionists. We report a large-scale experiment that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations did not enhance CCE, but that the incremental improvement in plane flight distance in the 1-Model social-learning condition was comparable to that in the Individual Learning condition. This suggests that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results highlight the importance of trial-and-error learning to artifact innovation and adaptation. They also suggest that the evolution of larger populations may be a side effect of the evolution of social learning. Our results have implications for the evolution of human culture and technology.

The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is associated with AD risk in a dose-dependent manner. APOE2 is associated with a decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE4 is associated with an increased risk. The mechanisms underlying this isoform-dependent AD risk are not known. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q-mediated synapse degeneration, which may be the mechanism underlying the increased AD risk of APOE4. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk due to defective astrocytic phagocytic capacity, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to complement-mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We show that the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron is much more likely than that of the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the stable phase of iron at the inner core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), is blunted in marijuana abusers, who also show increased negative emotionality and addiction. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

The language comprehension system is the most complex cognitive system in the human brain. It is also the most studied, but the mechanisms of its neural computation are still largely unknown. Here, we show that deep learning models can predict the neural responses of the language comprehension system with high accuracy. This suggests that the language comprehension system is a highly predictable computational system, and that the neural code of language comprehension may be more similar to that of a computer, such as a deep learning model, than previously thought.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning, but it is still a black box. We show that the instability of DL is due to the fact that we are using the wrong tools. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are well-conditioned for scientific computing, and we prove that they are stable. We also introduce a new type of neural network that is stable and fast. This work is a step toward understanding the stability of neural networks and the development of more stable and efficient DL algorithms.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community is currently debating the causes of the pandemic, with some arguing that people’s inability to understand exponential growth is a major factor. This article discusses a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago, which is often cited as evidence for this claim. The experiment’s critical design flaws were not recognized at the time, and the study’s conclusion was subsequently widely accepted. In hindsight, this is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes a reactional form of the disease. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is the first genome sequence of a leprosy bacterium. We also show that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of leprosy bacteria than is M. leprae. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be a more recent addition to the leprosy group of bacteria and may be a more recent pathogen of humans. This is important because M. lepromatosis is associated with a more severe form of leprosy, and may be a more important pathogen of humans than M. leprae. (Show more)

The dynamics of entanglement and entropy in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question of quantum physics. It is also of great relevance for the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in interacting quantum systems can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find perfect agreement with numerical simulations. Our work provides a new perspective on the entanglement dynamics and its connection to thermodynamics.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has affected millions of people worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a temperature-sensitive live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 strain, which is able to replicate efficiently at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is expected to be safe and effective in mass vaccination programs.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is still debated, with some studies suggesting that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, were the primary vectors. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work provides a new perspective on the history of plague in Europe and may have implications for the spread of other diseases in the past and present.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in neuroscience, but the evolution of brain neuronal density is still largely unknown. Here, we show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is as important as the evolution of brain size. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is as important as the evolution of brain size. We also show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is associated with the evolution of brain size.

The mitochondrial chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the role of TRAP1 in normal cells is less clear. We have shown that TRAP1 is required for the metabolic switch from oxidative phosphorylation to aerobic glycolysis and glucose deprivation in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1 also regulates the invasiveness of these cells. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is controlled by a family of proteins that are related to each other and to the cytoskeleton-severing protein ADF/cofilin. We show that this family of proteins can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We also show that the action of this family of proteins is enhanced by the mechanical torque that they induce on filament segments. This mechanism is critical to the ability of the proteins to sever highly connected filament networks, which is relevant to cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and food intake.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a rapid growth of the population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a new perspective on the history of the Indian Ocean islands. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a new way of studying the spread of emotions in social networks, and it suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not in the same room. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work has implications for the design of social media, and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in social networks.

The presence of mRNA modifications can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a single pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA (mRNA) can significantly reduce the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This study provides a deeper understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis and may lead to the development of new strategies for modulating protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. These associations are robust to the inclusion of factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or to the measurement of outcomes before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. The optimum size occurs at an intermediate value where thermoregulatory costs are low but feeding efficiency remains high. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common disease worldwide, and the virus responsible, rhinovirus, is the most common cause of this disease. The temperature at which the virus replicates most efficiently in the human body is not known. Here, we show that the common cold virus replicates preferentially at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity, where the temperature is maintained at 33–35 °C. We also show that the virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperature because the host cell responds less aggressively to the virus at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (Show more)

Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment. Here we show that the surface attachment of the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is sensed by its type IV pili, which are used for twitching motility and as a mechanochemical sensor. This mechanochemical model is supported by the observation that the pili-mediated surface sensing system is essential for the pathogenicity of P. aeruginosa in a mouse model of pneumonia. Our findings thus provide a mechanistic understanding of how bacteria sense their environment and how this information is used for bacterial adaptation and pathogenicity. This work also suggests that type IV pili can be used as a mechanosensitive sensor in bacteria. This work thus advances our understanding of the evolution of bacterial sensing systems and their impact on bacterial adaptation and pathogenicity. (Show more)

The use of pesticides in agriculture is a major driver of global biodiversity loss. The risk of pesticide contamination of surface water is often underestimated due to a lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a global metaanalysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in humans and animals is a major concern for the future of the pandemic. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 is circulating in deer during the winter, when human infections are rare. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our study highlights the need for a better understanding of the role of wildlife in the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the impacts of these dams, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to the presence of Aβ plaques, which are not present in all AD patients. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are the most toxic amyloid species within the brain and are responsible for the initiation of the AD-related immune response. We also demonstrate that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ is a significant risk factor for the development of the AD-related immune response, which may precede the formation of Aβ plaques. Our findings suggest that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. This study provides a new perspective on the AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is, however, still elusive. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal assemblage from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread at that site. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken and its spread in the ancient world. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have used this method to study the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in two distinct steps. The first step is a fast compaction of the protein into a polyglobular state. The second step is a slow formation of a native-like folding intermediate. The results suggest that the intermediate is an obligatory step in the folding process. This is an important step in our understanding of the folding process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. In this study, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing this cap, RppH, preferentially deprotects Np4-capped RNAs over their tri- and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation, reducing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells, and improving the survival of mice after sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy for sepsis.

The biomass of all living organisms on Earth is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass pyramid of the global marine food web contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a better understanding of the biomass of wild mammals. This work is a step forward in the effort to build a global biomass census. (Show more)

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in the plane. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized by strain engineering, which is a promising way to change the properties of diamond. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by strain engineering, which is a promising way to change the properties of graphite. Our findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for many applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. This study describes the discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides, NCR peptides, and their potential as a new class of fungicide. The structure of the first member of this class of peptides was solved, and it was shown to be a potent fungicide against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The mode of action of this peptide was also elucidated. This work provides a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a new class of fungicide. This work also provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this peptide. This work is expected to be of interest to the scientific community and the public.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and the extent of molecular continuity between the sexes is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm is modified after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract provides a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a key player in the blood clotting cascade. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that the A1 domain of VWF, which binds platelets, can be switched to a second state by force, which is a key physiological stimulus. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The mechanism is also relevant for other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that are essential for human health. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been difficult to study, and the number of studies is still small. This study is a major step forward in the field, as it provides a comprehensive database of viruses associated with humans. The database is a valuable resource for researchers studying the role of viruses in human health, and it will help to advance our understanding of the human virome.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI process is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. The main reason is that the ACI process is difficult to be observed. We introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe the aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. The instrument is used to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations show that the aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature history of the early Earth is a key issue in understanding the origin and early evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding the isotopic compositions of the oceans in the Archean, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes reconstructed from ancient organisms, which provide an independent method by which to assess the temperature history inferred from the isotopic evidence. Our results suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Abridged)

Ion channels are the gates of ion flow. They open and close their pore gates to allow or block ion flow. The pore gates are the main targets of drug binding and modulation. The activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery of K+ channels are the two main processes that regulate ion flow. We found that the BK channel’s activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery are closely related. The BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and its rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion flow by ion channels. (Show more)

The malaria parasite invades the human erythrocyte, the target of infection, and the Plasmodium parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) is required for this process. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to the erythrocyte surface leads to an increase in the tension of the red cell cytoskeleton and a reduction in the bending modulus of the membrane. We show that these changes in the red cell biophysical properties correlate with the ability of the parasite to invade the erythrocyte. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal conductivity. It is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized by strain engineering, and the electronic and phonon structures can be controlled by machine learning. This work provides a new way to tailor the properties of diamond for applications. It also provides a new way to understand the properties of diamond, which is a key material for many applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The impact of environmental factors on influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may lead to the development of new strategies for influenza prevention and treatment. (Show more)

The brain is thought to build a syntactic structure of a sentence by successively merging words into phrases. Whether and how this merge operation is implemented in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple regions of the brain increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a left-corner parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may help to explain the speed with which the brain processes language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major regulator of development and physiology. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its two forms are genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, and that the differential regulation confers tissue-specific responsiveness. This is an example of the importance of subtle differences in gene regulation, which may be important in the development of tissue-specific functions.

The brain circuit that promotes overeating is not well understood. Here we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces rapid vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the hunger or satiety mechanisms that govern normal feeding. Instead, we propose that this circuit is involved in the regulation of food intake in the context of obesity.

The ability of plants to fix nitrogen (N2) is a key feature of the terrestrial food chain and a major driver of plant productivity. However, the ability of plants to control the activity of their symbiotic bacteria, which fix N2, is limited. Here, we demonstrate a method to control the activity of a symbiotic bacterium in a plant, using a synthetic signaling system. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is expected to have a major impact on the field of synthetic biology and on the development of sustainable agriculture.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management. The program’s monitors were perceived as new authorities with influence over forest management, and the monitors’ patrols were perceived as substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

The ability to hear is a fundamental sense for all animals, including all mammals, birds, some reptiles, amphibians, fish, and arthropods. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein mediates viral entry to cells via ACE2. We engineered the RBD sequence to improve its manufacturability, affinity to ACE2, and immunogenicity. The engineered RBD variant was presented on a designed VLP, which reduced weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. The engineered RBD variant is expected to be a useful addition to the global vaccine arsenal.

The role of the ALK/ALKALS receptor–ligand pair in neural crest development is unknown. Here, we show that zebrafish ALKALS are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish skin. We further show that ALKALS are able to activate the ALK/ALKALS receptor complex in vitro and in vivo. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of the ALKALS in the development of iridophores and suggest a role of the ALKALS in the regulation of neural crest development.

The emergence of plague as a devastating pathogen in human history is a topic of great interest. The study of ancient pathogens is challenging, as the number of recovered genomes is too few to explore their diversity. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age period, which is a critical period for the development of the disease. We show that the disease underwent a series of evolutionary steps, and that the number of genomes is not sufficient to explore the diversity of the disease during this period. We also show that the disease was not restricted to a single lineage, but rather underwent a rapid expansion across Eurasia. This study provides new insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship with its hosts. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted support for Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also suggest that HM may be a target for intervention to reduce support for patriarchal dominance and the political polarization that it fosters.

The management of agricultural systems can influence the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. This study shows that the management of annual cropping systems on grassland-derived Mollisols can increase the amount of C stored in the soil. The most effective management practices were reduced tillage, diversified crop rotations with cover crops and legumes, and manure addition. These practices increased the amount of carbon stored in the soil and in the more stable mineral-associated organic matter. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester carbon and the importance of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of wildlife viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. SpillOver is a resource that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators for visitation. The color of this reward is often an important factor in attracting pollinators. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the blood-red flower Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify this trait in two other plants visited by nectar-feeding vertebrates. This work suggests that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid with potential pharmaceutical applications. (Show more)

We present a study of the genetic ancestry of women from the early medieval period in Europe. We show that women had a very high genetic heterogeneity, which included signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking is the genetic ancestry of women with artificial skull deformations, which suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides new insights into the complex demographic processes that occurred during the early medieval period. It also demonstrates the potential of ancient DNA studies to provide information on the genetic history of European populations.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV and the origins of bat coronaviruses. They also suggest that the use of DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses as a vaccine vector should be avoided. (Show more)

We describe the use of a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of mNGS to detect a broad range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings, where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. This approach can be used to better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This work is a step toward a more comprehensive understanding of the pathogen landscape in resource-scarce settings.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication fork progression. This process is catalyzed by the enzyme DNA polymerase δ (pol δ). The stability of pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of replication. We designed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Surprisingly, the results indicate that human pol δ maintains a loose association with proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique insight into the mechanism of pol δ holoenzyme stability and its implications on the replication process. This work also provides a unique insight into the mechanism of pol δ holoenzyme stability and its implications on the replication process. (Show more)

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. In this paper, we describe the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself. This is a major step forward in our understanding of the origin of life, as it provides a mechanism for the evolution of RNA molecules that can replicate themselves.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes of cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is still in the stage of clinical trial. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which is a monoclonal antibody targeting the IL-6 pathways, is effective in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a new treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but it is also a toxic metal that can damage cells. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-derived metabolites suggests a role for these molecules in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this pathway is important for the maintenance of copper homeostasis and the control of interactions with competing microbes.

The formation of silica in the martian environment is a key to understanding the origin of the Martian surface. The detection of tridymite in the sedimentary rocks of the Curiosity landing site is a significant step forward in this understanding. Tridymite is a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of silica that is formed by the action of high-temperature, high-pressure fluids on silicates. The detection of tridymite in the sedimentary rocks of the Curiosity landing site suggests that the fluids responsible for its formation were derived from the wall of the crater.

The impact of late-spring frosts (LSFs) on plants and animals is well known, but the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of LSFs is associated with the leaf-out strategies of trees, and that the increasing frequency of LSFs in some regions is likely to increase the frost damage to trees. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk. Our results also provide a framework to study the impact of other environmental perturbations on plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis and may be a target for the development of new therapies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from human fibroblasts, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapeutics. We also show that motor neurons are highly sensitive to astrocyte-derived toxicity, and that this toxicity is a common feature of ALS. This method will enable the study of disease mechanisms and the rapid testing of potential therapeutics to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity in ALS. It will also enable the study of the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases, and in the development of neuroprotective therapies. This work will help to improve the lives of ALS patients. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of human pathogens. We now show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. We also show that the protein binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, which alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in evolution. The discovery of a new early member of the group of birds with a short tail ending in a pygostyle adds important information about the origin of the modern avian body plan. The new taxon, named Jinguofortis, is an important addition to the growing diversity of early pygostylians, which are critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan.

The climate system is a coupled system, and the climate response to a change in forcing depends on the coupling between the different components of the system. In this paper, we show that the coupling between the troposphere and the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate response to a change in solar radiation.

The presence of blue-green tissues in vertebrates is a unique and striking feature of their biology. The biochemical basis of this phenomenon, its evolution, and its function are poorly understood. Here, we describe the molecular and functional basis of the evolution of chlorosis in anurans (frogs and toads). We also describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide a molecular and functional basis for the evolution of chlorosis, and a new function for a serpin. This work also provides a new tool for the study of serpins and their functions. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. We show that hypoxia induces the expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a pluripotency factor, and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. This study provides a mechanism for the induction of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment is a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, such as rabbit, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future, and it may also be possible to use it to identify the animal origin of paper. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical for understanding the cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model shows that the extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill

The intestinal epithelium is the first line of defense against the environment. It is essential to maintain intestinal homeostasis to prevent the development of inflammatory diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying intestinal inflammation are not fully understood. Here, we report that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. We also find that RORα/HDAC3-mediated NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence and absence of the D614G mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent membrane fusion. These results provide insights into the mechanism of the D614G mutation and may help to design vaccines and therapeutics that target the spike protein. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even in the case of a single player. The result is also new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are infinite. The result is new even in the case of a single player when the action sets are countable and the set of players is countably infinite.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, and Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two of the most important properties of atoms, and they are the basis of many chemical models. We show that these properties change with pressure, and we discover that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

We show that human ignitions and suppression have been the dominant driver of global fire activity for the last century. This has led to a warming trend, but we also show that the trajectory of human ignitions and suppression will determine whether this trend continues or reverses. We find that the reduction in ignitions and suppression in recent decades has already started to attenuate warming. However, this effect is likely to be short lived, and we show that climate change will likely continue to drive warming for the next century. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to better understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and carbon. This is critical for understanding the future trajectory of the global carbon cycle and climate.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microorganisms is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. We propose that this glycan is a nutrient that is provided to the squid at dusk, when the symbiotic organ is at its most vulnerable, and that its catabolism modulates the conditions in which the symbionts live. This glycan-mediated regulation of symbiosis may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their associated microorganisms. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a sparse representation of word embeddings to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent discourse atoms. We can infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We hope it will be useful to researchers in many fields.
