The Black Death, which occurred in the 14th century, is the most devastating epidemic in human history. The disease was likely introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague. This bacterium was then reintroduced into Europe, via the trade routes, on multiple occasions. Our results suggest that the climate conditions in Asia were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the disease was not introduced into Europe from a permanent plague reservoir. This finding has implications for our understanding of the second plague pandemic, which lasted for four centuries. (Show more)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is one of the most devastating diseases of marine invertebrates. The disease is caused by a virus that has spread rapidly across the Pacific coast of North America. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease and that it has been present on the Pacific coast for at least 72 y. The discovery of the virus is a major advance in our understanding of the disease and the potential for its spread.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of blood cancer, and the prognosis is poor. The IL1RAP (IL1R3) is expressed on AML cells, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP is able to kill AML cells in vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, we show that the antibody is able to block IL-1 signaling, which is important for the growth of AML cells. These results provide evidence that IL1RAP is a promising target for the treatment of AML.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island has a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened recently, with a rapid growth of the population. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the colonization of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia. Finally, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a new perspective on the history of human colonization of the Indian Ocean islands. (Show more)

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases its activity. We also show that the RNA base pairs with the cadA and galE promoters and that the base pairing interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions of the RNA compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past. The discovery of this RNA is important because it demonstrates that the translation and base-pairing functions of sRNAs compete with each other. This is an important observation because it suggests that the two functions of a given sRNA may be regulated by the same mechanism. This is a general principle that may be important for understanding the regulation of many sRNAs.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on the status of crops in the field. However, their assessments are subjective and qualitative, and are not easily amenable to quantitative analysis. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the subjective assessments of a large number of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict yields. We also show that the survey data are stable over time, and can be used to monitor the status of crops in different regions of the country. Finally, we demonstrate how the survey data can be used to monitor crop conditions and predict yields, and show that the resulting Crop Condition Index is more accurate than official USDA forecasts. This work opens the door to a new era of crop monitoring, where the expertise of the crop experts is fully utilized to provide more accurate and timely information on the status of crops.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major carbon flux in the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the response of soil respiration to warming is highly variable across studies, and the magnitude of the response is uncertain. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, and we find no evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types. Our results suggest that soil respiration may decrease with increasing temperature, which could have important implications for the global carbon cycle.

The transition from autotrophy to parasitism is one of the most significant events in the evolution of life on Earth. It is also one of the most difficult to model, because the functional consequences of the transition are not known. Here, we show that the transition to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 drought by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 80% by the year 2100 under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results emphasize the need for urgent mitigation efforts to reduce the risk of future droughts in SSA.

The discovery of a new quasicrystal in trinitite, the material left behind from the first nuclear explosion, is a unique and remarkable event. It is the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal, and it provides a link between the discovery of quasicrystals and the development of nuclear weapons.

Photosynthesis is the basis of life on Earth. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is accomplished by chlorophyll, a molecule that is modified in a number of ways. The biosynthesis of these modified tetrapyrroles is catalyzed by a number of enzymes, some of which are related, and some of which are not. This paper describes the evolution of the enzymes that catalyze the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in chlorophyll.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 is involved in the development of experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), a mouse model of multiple sclerosis. We also found that ASK1 is required for the development of EAE in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes, but not in T cells and dendritic cells. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in the development of EAE and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities. We also show that the probability of drought has increased if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. These findings have important implications for climate change adaptation and mitigation efforts.

Autism is a complex disorder with a large number of risk genes and a variety of environmental factors. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core symptoms of autism. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility, which resulted from the inability to forget. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This finding provides a mechanistic understanding of the core symptoms of autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. (Show more)

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of the STIM1 Ca2+ sensor that result in a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and miosis. We also identify mutations in the ORAI1 pore-forming protein that result in a Stormorken-like syndrome of miosis and tubular myopathy, but without hematological abnormalities. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of CRAC channel dysregulation, and suggest new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is a noncell-autonomous process that leads to the death of vulnerable neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the membrane, demonstrating that the active process of release is important for the spread of aggregates and disease. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The immune system of bats is considered to be highly specialized and immune privileged, which is believed to be an important factor in the maintenance of the bat’s health and survival. However, the immune system of bats is not immune to infection. Here, we identified a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and found that MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host. MTX also inhibits the generation of proinflammatory leukotriene B4 (LTB4) and the activity of proinflammatory proteases. This study provides deeper insight into the immune system of bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This work may help to develop a new class of antiviral drugs that are effective against a wide range of viruses. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is critical for the production of the one-carbon unit. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts, and that it is particularly effective in B-cell lines. We also show that the one-carbon unit donor formate is a potent rescue of SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in a lymphoma cell line. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for cancer treatment. (Show more)

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that the disease is associated with a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. We show that the average supersaturation of the coaggregating proteins is greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, but not when the supersaturation is calculated from other human tissues. These results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS results from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the coaggregating proteins are highly aggregation-prone. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The system is predicted to produce exotic quantum phenomena, including suppressed spontaneous emission, atom–atom interactions, and emission in a directionally controlled manner. The system can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process. The system can be used to study many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The system can be used to study the physics of the quantum vacuum, the Casimir–Polder interaction, and the role of the quantum vacuum in the formation of the first stars. The system can be used to study the physics of the quantum vacuum, the Casimir–Polder interaction, and the role of the quantum vacuum in the formation of the first stars.

The Cretaceous is a key time in the history of life, with the origin of many major groups. The origin of the flowering plants is a major event in the Cretaceous, but the exact time and place of the origin of the flowering plants are poorly understood. The study of the early flowering plant Montsechia provides new information about the early evolution of the flowering plants.

The evolution of viruses is a key topic in molecular biology, and it is of great interest to understand the evolution of the human pathogen B19V. Here we present the genomes of five ancient B19V strains, which are all basal to the most common B19V genotype, and five basal to the second most common genotype. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the second most common genotype to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and the rate of rise is accelerating. The causes are well known, but the rate of acceleration is not. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of acceleration of global mean sea level. The results are in agreement with the IPCC AR5 model projections, but the paper is more comprehensive and the results are more precise.

Pain is a common and costly problem, and the elderly are more likely to report pain than those in midlife. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain prevalence has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is a key determinant of the reaction pathway and the rate and selectivity of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. The structure of the enzyme–substrate complex is difficult to obtain, however, because the substrate is not bound in a stable conformation. Here, we show how NMR-assisted crystallography can be used to obtain the structure of the enzyme–substrate complex, and how this structure can be used to understand the mechanism of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a newly emerged coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of great importance in the fight against the current outbreak of COVID-19.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and quantity of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a glycan to its symbiotic bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a manner that is synchronized with the activity of the symbiont. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to maintain the health of their symbionts and, in some cases, to control the activity of the symbiosis. This work provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbiosis and the evolution of nutrient delivery strategies. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The results are consistent across settings and suggest that this intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. This is a scalable, evidence-based intervention that can be implemented in schools around the world.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage and is involved in the etiology of a variety of human diseases. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (EtdT) lesions on pol II transcription. We found that pol II is stalled at the EtdT lesions, and the stalling is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also found that the EtdT lesions can induce multiple transcriptional bypass routes, and the error-free route is favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route is observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II, which is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes pneumonia in humans. To better understand the pathogenesis of MERS-CoV, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked the sequential proteolytic events required for virus entry. We found that these mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into other cell types. These findings suggest that the sequential proteolytic events required for virus entry are important determinants of MERS-CoV virulence.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering environment can have a significant impact on meal selection behavior. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering environments is a simple and effective way to promote more sustainable diets.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to analyze the surface proteome of cells, and applied it to a collection of six oncogenes that are the most common drivers of breast cancer. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common themes including the up-regulation of nutrient transporters and the down-regulation of adhesion molecules. We also show that the surfaceome is remodeled by the oncogenes, and that this is accompanied by changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. However, the effects of vote-by-mail have not been systematically studied. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and the molecular basis for this is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune suppression. This work provides insight into the mechanisms of immune evasion and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can induce cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and neuronal apoptosis in cultured cortical neurons. We also show that the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus is increased, and that CRF acts on the cerebral cortex to induce edema. We further show that CRF acts on astrocytes to induce water influx and edema. Finally, we show that CRF acts on astrocytes to induce water influx and edema. These findings provide a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies for this disease. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. We hope that this will help readers to understand the strengths and limitations of these and other methods for finding significant associations in large datasets.

The development of vascular ECs is a complex process that requires the cooperation of multiple transcription factors. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) is a key factor in the development of vascular ECs. ETV2 is able to induce the expression of endothelial development factors in both primary human skin fibroblasts and human induced pluripotent stem cells. In addition, ETV2 is able to induce the formation of mature vascular networks in NOD SCID mice. These results indicate that ETV2 is a promising factor for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular ECs and the formation of vascular networks. (Show more)

The discovery of ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively) as ligands of the oncogenic receptor tyrosine kinases ALK and LTK has opened up a new field of research. In this paper, we show that these ligands are essential for the development of the zebrafish iridophores, which are responsible for the coloration of the eye and the skin. We also show that the two ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the skin, but not of the skin coloration. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a better understanding of the role of ALK and LTK in the development of the nervous system and the immune system. It also provides a new perspective on the role of ALK and LTK in the development of the skin and the eye.

The role of STING in β-cell function and insulin secretion is still unclear. Herein, we found that STING is decreased in islets of db/db mice and patients with T2D, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING-deficient β-cells showed impaired GSIS, which was associated with the loss of nuclear localization of Pax6. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of β-cell function and insulin secretion, and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings may provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza. They are divided into subtypes, which are further divided into lineages. The evolution of these lineages is not well understood. Here, we identified a mechanism that limits the evolution of influenza A viruses. We found that the viral genome can promote the selective packaging of the viral genome into the viral particles. This mechanism is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses, which might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our results provide a mechanism that limits the evolution of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of factors. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. YAP/TAZ knockdown significantly attenuated the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. In addition, treatment with statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited YAP/TAZ activities to diminish the disturbed flow-induced proliferation and inflammation. Wildfires are a natural and important part of many ecosystems, but they can also be destructive. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to monitor the physical changes of cities over time and to study the spatial dynamics of urban change. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a group of plant-derived compounds that are used to protect humans and animals from insect bites. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods are still unclear. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel that senses natural repellents, and demonstrated that this channel is essential for the avoidance behavior. This study provides a new approach to the development of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It also demonstrates the evolutionary adaptation of arthropods to the plant world. (Show more)

The Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection. In the case of favipiravir, a polymerase inhibitor with activity against ZIKV, we predict a dose of 150 mg/kg given twice a day initiated at the time of infection can reduce the peak median viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median viral load by ∼2 d. Our results provide a quantitative assessment of the potential impact of antiviral treatment on the outcome of ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most biologically diverse ecosystems on Earth. However, they are also among the most threatened marine habitats. The breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algal partners is the most severe threat to coral reefs today. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbiont are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. This work is a major step forward in our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis.

The intestinal epithelium is the main barrier between the host and the environment. It is also the main site of nutrient absorption and immune surveillance. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is a highly dynamic tissue that is constantly responding to the presence of tumors and the microbiome. We also show that the activity of the JNK pathway is a key determinant of the intestinal epithelium’s ability to maintain the integrity of the barrier. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides a potential mechanism for extending the lifespan of Drosophila. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to this treatment is heterogeneous. We show that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy, which enhances the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). We also show that ROR1 expression enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab, in combination with paclitaxel, is more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this explanation is highly improbable. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation plausibly led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a global climate response, including a shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, and thus to a change in the Southern Hemisphere climate system.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food, recreation, and commerce, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, particularly in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors. Our data can be used to identify areas where fisheries are most likely to contribute to food security and biodiversity conservation. This information can help to inform the design of sustainable fisheries management and conservation policies.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult mammalian CNS. This discovery opens the door to a new platform for studying the molecular mechanisms that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the genome as a whole. The distribution of recombination activity in a genome is a key determinant of its genetic architecture. Here, we describe the distribution of recombination activity in a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus, and compare it to that in yeast and in mice. We find that the distribution of recombination activity in plants is similar to that in yeast, suggesting that recombination initiation in eukaryotes may be conserved. We also find that recombination activity in plants is more polarized than in yeast, suggesting that the polarity of recombination activity in eukaryotes may also be conserved. These results provide a foundation for understanding the genetic architecture of plants and other eukaryotes.

The brain is organized in networks of functionally related regions. The present study provides a method to identify and validate resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. The method is based on the analysis of metabolic imaging, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total neuronal activity. The method was validated in healthy subjects and in Parkinson’s disease patients, who showed a reduction in the expression of the dominant metabolic network. The method can be used to identify and characterize the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation initiation and is the target of many antiviral and anticancer drugs. The existence of 5′ cap analogs in bacteria has been known for decades, but the existence of 5′ cap analogs in eukaryotes has been unknown. We show that 5′ cap analogs are found in yeast, and that they are produced cotranscriptionally. This discovery has implications for the regulation of gene expression in eukaryotes.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive therapy could prevent the development of diabetes complications. However, the long-term effects of this therapy are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells are associated with the DCCT intensive therapy during the DCCT and the development of diabetes complications in the long-term follow-up. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

The role of a protein in cancer is determined by its expression level, function, and interaction with other proteins. We identified a protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), that is highly expressed in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells impairs the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs. Computational modeling revealed that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was confirmed by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic, relapsing, and progressive disease, which is characterized by a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant number of alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and that it could be a target in the management of this disease.

The production of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit is essential for the development of the fruit aroma. However, the biosynthesis of these compounds is not known. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. The gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation of a tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid substrate. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of these important aroma compounds and opens the way for the development of improved tomato cultivars with enhanced flavor. We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. This is important because temperature is one of the most important drivers of ecosystem change and biodiversity loss. Our results suggest that the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning will be more severe if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits. This is a significant finding because it highlights the need to consider the combined effects of climate change and biodiversity loss in the management of ecosystems.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is critical for spatial memory. The organization of MEC is important for understanding the formation of spatial representations in the brain. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that the spatial tuning of grid cells is distinct from that of border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These findings provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and its connections with other brain regions. They also provide a platform for future studies of the formation of spatial representations in the brain. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of factors. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) is required for the flowering of both the host and the parasite of the root- and leafless dodder plant parasite. This finding illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a unique example of a flowering signal that is able to synchronize flowering of two different species.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers, which are the major pathway for dopamine to the striatum, originate from striosomes, a region of the nucleus accumbens that is thought to be involved in reward and decision-making. We also show that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to mood and motivation and that striosomes link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. We propose that striosomes are involved in the control of movement and motivation and that striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. This signal is used by people to evaluate the quality of their connections with others, and by listeners to evaluate the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for our understanding of social connection, and for the design of technologies that can help people feel more connected.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the electrical impulse that drives the heart. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its automaticity is regulated by a number of factors. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the automaticity of the SAN.

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. In this study, we show that Si can enhance the resistance of rice against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact with each other in the priming of defense responses against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the function of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages and for the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage activation.

Language is a complex system that is thought to be based on the ability to integrate information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is adaptive, meaning that it changes in response to experience. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We also show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of the siRNA to the target gene. We also show that the delivery of the siRNA to the target gene depends on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a significant step forward in the field of plant biology.

The coastal zone is a critical ecosystem that provides many of the services we rely on, including food, water, and recreation. However, the coastal zone is also the first to be impacted by nutrient pollution, which can lead to harmful algal blooms and oxygen depletion. We show that the coastal zone is not only impacted by nutrients from large rivers, but also by nutrients from small streams that drain into the lake. These small streams are often overlooked in nutrient management efforts, but our results suggest that they may be a significant source of nutrients to the coastal zone. Our findings highlight the importance of small streams in nutrient pollution and the need to address them in nutrient management efforts.

We study the dynamics of a network of chemical reactions in a thermodynamic environment that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a ratchet, but the environment is not driven by an external force. Rather, the environment is driven by the rare combinations of chemical concentrations that are able to access the thermodynamic force.

We show that NMDAR-Abs can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities by disrupting the dynamics of the brain. This is a major advance in our understanding of the mechanisms of this disease, which is a major clinical challenge. This work also has implications for the treatment of this disease.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million years. To understand the potential impacts of such warming, it is important to understand the Earth system response to past abrupt warming events. Here, we present a study of an abrupt global warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the warming event was accompanied by a global-scale perturbation of the carbon cycle, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million years.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification appears to be most effective in reducing deforestation in areas with the least residual forest cover. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a key regulator of the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 subunits, and the function of each subunit is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

The evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study in developmental biology. In this paper, we show that the multiple alleles of a single locus can produce a modular system of sex determination, where the same genotype can produce different phenotypes. This modular system can produce a variety of phenotypes, including different sexes, and can be used to understand the evolution of sex determination in a variety of species.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct types of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that are generated by photoreceptor cells and by the surrounding retinal pigment epithelium (RPE). The RPE is also challenged by the accumulation of a lipid-soluble fluorescent metabolite of vitamin A that is oxidized and degraded by ROS. We show that the levels of iron (Fe) in the retina, as reflected in the expression of the transferrin receptor, impacts the levels of ROS and the degradation of a fluorescent metabolite of vitamin A. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (Read more)

The evolution of specialization is a central topic in ecology and evolution. In this paper, we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a process that has led to the evolution of specialization on different prey types. This process is driven by the evolution of the tentilla, the structures that are specialized for prey capture. Our results provide a broader perspective on the evolution of specialization, and help us understand how specialization has shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in human evolution, but the origins of the distinctive features of the hand that are shared with Neandertals are poorly understood. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from the Middle Pleistocene of Kenya that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key feature of the human hand and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of Neandertal uniqueness. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of cell growth, and one-carbon metabolism is a key regulator of cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon metabolism enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also show that the inhibitor is effective in inhibiting the growth of a number of cancer cell lines, but is particularly effective in inhibiting B-cell lines. This is a significant finding, as B-cell lines are the most common type of cancer cell line used in cancer cell-line screens. Thus, we propose that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for treating B-cell cancers.

The results of this study have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The results suggest that, in addition to agricultural intensification, forests can be considered as a potential source of food and nutrition security. This study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. The results are important for the development of evidence-based policies to improve food and nutrition security.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
